text: I have a strategy that performs really well over 2 months of backtesting data. Looks great on the MC analysis as well. However it performs dismally on the verification/test data, to the point od only breaking even. I can't figure out if I'm overfitting (I don't want to look at any of the verification data so I dont overfit that too), but i dont think my parameters are overly complicated (only 4 variables). Is it normal that this happens or could something else be going wrong? Thanks

text: Cross validation

elements.text: Cross validation

text: from a ML perspective but I think it generally applies, is that you have some form of loss function (a way to measure performance), you take iterative steps changing values of the signal which decrease this loss function in training set. Then you would predict the estimates for the test set in that step and if its loss decreases also then you continue repeating, until teh point where a change to the signal value decreases the loss in the training set but increases the loss in the test set

elements.text: from a ML perspective but I think it generally applies, is that you have some form of loss function (a way to measure performance), you take iterative steps changing values of the signal which decrease this loss function in training set. Then you would predict the estimates for the test set in that step and if its loss decreases also then you continue repeating, until teh point where a change to the signal value decreases the loss in the training set but increases the loss in the test set

text:
Sounds like you’re overfitting, but the real problem is that it’s just not enough bets to confirm whether the strategy works or not. 

Over a 2 month period really you need to be aiming for 10 or 100 times that number of bets. Otherwise you’re just not going to be able to scale it unless you have some massive edge.

elements.text: Sounds like you’re overfitting, but the real problem is that it’s just not enough bets to confirm whether the strategy works or not.
Over a 2 month period really you need to be aiming for 10 or 100 times that number of bets. Otherwise you’re just not going to be able to scale it unless you have some massive edge.

text: You can create a simple Monte Carlo sim using code or spreadsheet and see what results you could have got if the race results were random based on the prices you matched as the true probabilities. Then run the sim lots of times to see the probability your backtest could have come from a random outcome.

elements.text: You can create a simple Monte Carlo sim using code or spreadsheet and see what results you could have got if the race results were random based on the prices you matched as the true probabilities. Then run the sim lots of times to see the probability your backtest could have come from a random outcome.

text:
For me, 4 parameters is starting to get quite a lot as well. Personally, most my strategies have 1-2. And at least one of those parameters will be a variable thresholding parameter. 

What you can try is to vary your parameters a bit and see if the backtest still works nearly as well. If it doesn’t, then you’re just backfitting to data. Any parameters you have should be “robust” and returns a nice “shape” improving as you get closer to an optimal value and decreasing as you vary away from the optimum value, and not work only for very specific parameter values.

Any parameters you have should be “robust” and returns a nice “shape” improving as you get closer to an optimal value and decreasing as you vary away from the optimum value, and not work only for very specific parameter values.

text: <@U01S1VB9X9P> yes, that looks like an overfit to me. I wouldn't put too much faith in that MC simulator  as it's only intended as a sanity check. For backtesting, what I've found to be more useful is to plot the theoretical 100% match rate vs your simulated P&L. That will show whether you're on the right side of value, even if the simulated P&L is negative. From there, you can then attempt to improve match rates while reducing adverse selection. Easier said than done, though!
